text:
I was interested to see how you measured success. I would like to have seen:
- comparison against alternative courses
- measurements other than student feedback

I suspect a charming lecturer will score highly irrespective of the course content!

I like the motivation but as someone from industry not academia, I would want you to go much further! It sounds like the assignments are all greenfield work. I'd like a PL design course to give students a 1M LOC dump of code and some rearchitecting goals. Can they understand the code and successfully refactor it?

From a PL design point of view, it's the real test of a language and it's type system that I care about in practice and as an employer, it's the real-world skill I want students to learn.

I am horrified by the waste we have in industry due to "legacy code" and rewrites which I fear is more about our difficulty to grok and maintain large code-bases than anything else.

Thanks for the feedback! Alas yes, this was not a scientific comparison, as there are few meaningful quantitative measurements of course quality. The point of this essay is moreso to discuss the curriculum than to make a sound claim about the outcomes.

<@UFD2JRE58> it would be interesting to know what kind of refactoring tasks you consider most challenging. I’ve considered such assignments in the past, but I haven’t been able to find the right balance of challenging, meaningful, and doable in a week.

text:
<@UFB8STN7K>

Oooh - good question!

It's quite project specific about what would work. I think I would collaborate with project maintainer to look over the history of a real codebase for a suitable bug/feature that has been already been completed so you can assess the actual changes required.

It may not be a good assignment on an open source project if the answer is just sat there on GitHub! Might need to find an old deprecated project that isn't so accessible anymore. Anything on sourceforge lol.

A better idea might be collaborating with a local company who has a suitable project. Good opportunity for the company to learn something too.

text: The only concern I have with this approach is that while this is certainly sensible for a software engineering class, a programming language theory class has different requirements. Such an assignment would need to not just show how to solve bugs in the real world, but to demonstrate how specific features of programming languages (and ideally type systems) are uniquely useful in making the refactoring process more productive.

text: (This is, generally speaking, the biggest point that I think most functional programming education misses---FP matters a lot in the real world b/c a rich type system make collaboration possible, but this point is difficult to make in the context of small, bite-sized assignments.)
